analyzeResult.content:
Heult & Science 13052
XPE SACRAMENTO BEE WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1981
His Smoke Gets In Her Lungs
How do you maintain a healthy marriage? Not Ismoking may be one answer. A Japanese "study recently published in the British Medical Journal strongly indicates that non-smoking wives exposed to their husband's cigarette smoke develop lung cancer at a higher rate than .those whose husbands are non-smokers. More- : over, the risk grows in direct proportion to the amount of smoking in the home. Overall, the death rates from lung cancer were twice as high for wives of heavy smokers.
The 14-year study by Dr. Takeshi Hirayama, of the National Cancer Center Research Insti- tute in Tokyo, is particularly significant because â€žit's the first to directly link secondhand smoke "to a disease as serious as lung cancer. Some crit- " fes contend Hirayama exaggerates the dangers - of. secondhand smoke; still, the exhaustive study - adds to the collection of evidence that ambient ""smoke isn't merely a minor social annoyance, "but a real health hazard. A study reported in the
New England Journal of Medicine last year found that non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke in the workplace suffer lung damage similar to that of persons who smoke from one to 10 cigarettes a day.
More importantly, Hirayama's study should give greater urgency to the need for legislation to protect non-smokers' rights to breathe clean air by restricting smoking in public buildings and places of public assembly. Proposition 10, the Smoking and No-Smoking Sections Initiative, tried to respond to that concern. Its rejection last November may have stemmed not from its intent, but from some vague and worrisome provisions, which, once adopted in initiative form, would be difficult to amend. Its defeat at the polls, however, didn't negate the need for a reasonable no-smoking law which, if passed by the Legislature, could also be amended by ft. The weight of medical evidence makes the need clear.
03740027
-- :selected: :unselected: :unselected:

How do you maintain a healthy marriage? Not Ismoking may be one answer. A Japanese "study recently published in the British Medical Journal strongly indicates that non-smoking wives exposed to their husband's cigarette smoke develop lung cancer at a higher rate than .those whose husbands are non-smokers. More- : over, the risk grows in direct proportion to the amount of smoking in the home. Overall, the death rates from lung cancer were twice as high for wives of heavy smokers.

The 14-year study by Dr. Takeshi Hirayama, of the National Cancer Center Research Insti- tute in Tokyo, is particularly significant because â€žit's the first to directly link secondhand smoke "to a disease as serious as lung cancer. Some crit- " fes contend Hirayama exaggerates the dangers - of. secondhand smoke; still, the exhaustive study - adds to the collection of evidence that ambient ""smoke isn't merely a minor social annoyance, "but a real health hazard. A study reported in the
New England Journal of Medicine last year found that non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke in the workplace suffer lung damage similar to that of persons who smoke from one to 10 cigarettes a day.

More importantly, Hirayama's study should give greater urgency to the need for legislation to protect non-smokers' rights to breathe clean air by restricting smoking in public buildings and places of public assembly. Proposition 10, the Smoking and No-Smoking Sections Initiative, tried to respond to that concern. Its rejection last November may have stemmed not from its intent, but from some vague and worrisome provisions, which, once adopted in initiative form, would be difficult to amend. Its defeat at the polls, however, didn't negate the need for a reasonable no-smoking law which, if passed by the Legislature, could also be amended by ft.
